caption: Table 1: The recommendation performance of linear mapping comparing with classical CF baselines.
description: This table presents a comparison of the recommendation performance achieved by a linear mapping method against several established collaborative filtering (CF) baselines.  The metrics used for comparison are Recall@20, NDCG@20, and HR@20, evaluated across three datasets (Books, Movies & TV, and Video Games).  The table shows the performance of different Language Models (LMs) used in the linear mapping approach, illustrating the potential of leveraging LM representations for recommendation tasks.

caption: Table 3: The performance comparison with ID-based CF baselines. The improvement achieved by AlphaRec is significant (p-value << 0.05).
description: This table compares the recommendation performance of AlphaRec against several ID-based Collaborative Filtering (CF) baselines across three datasets: Books, Movies & TV, and Video Games.  The metrics used are Recall@20, NDCG@20, and HR@20, which measure the effectiveness of the recommendation models. The p-value being significantly less than 0.05 indicates that AlphaRec's superior performance is statistically significant.

caption: Table 4: The zero-shot recommendation performance comparison on entirely new datasets. The improvement achieved by AlphaRec is significant (p-value << 0.05).
description: This table presents the results of a zero-shot recommendation experiment.  The model, AlphaRec, was trained on three Amazon datasets (Books, Movies & TV, and Video Games) and then tested on three completely new datasets (MovieLens-1M, Book Crossing, and Industrial) without any further training. The table compares AlphaRec's performance to several baselines (MF, MultVAE, LightGCN, Random, Pop, ZESRec, and UniSRec) using Recall@20, NDCG@20, and HR@20. The significant improvements of AlphaRec over the baselines demonstrate its ability to generalize well to unseen datasets.
section: 4.2 Zero-shot Recommendation Performance on Entirely New Datasets (RQ2)

caption: Table 6: Linear mapping performance of randomly shuffled item representations
description: This table compares the performance of linear mapping using randomly shuffled item representations against the performance using the original text embeddings.  It demonstrates the importance of the inherent structure and information within the original embeddings generated by the LM, rather than simply using random vectors of the same dimensionality. The results are presented for three metrics (Recall@20, NDCG@20, HR@20) across three datasets (Books, Movies & TV, Video Games).  The significant difference in performance between the original embeddings and the shuffled ones highlights that the LMs encode collaborative signals which are lost when the order of the embeddings is disrupted.

caption: Table 7: Dataset statistics.
description: This table presents the statistics of six datasets used in the paper's experiments.  For each dataset, it shows the number of users, items, and interactions (user-item pairs), as well as the density of the interaction matrix (the ratio of observed interactions to the total number of possible interactions). The datasets include three Amazon datasets (Books, Movies & TV, Video Games) and three other commonly used datasets in recommendation research (Industrial, MovieLens-1M, Book Crossing).  The diversity of these datasets in terms of size and domain allows for a comprehensive evaluation of the proposed model's performance.

caption: Table 3: The performance comparison with ID-based CF baselines. The improvement achieved by AlphaRec is significant (p-value << 0.05).
description: This table compares the performance of AlphaRec against several other ID-based collaborative filtering methods across three datasets (Books, Movies & TV, and Video Games).  The metrics used are Recall@20, NDCG@20, and HR@20.  AlphaRec significantly outperforms all baselines across all three datasets, demonstrating its effectiveness and efficiency.  The p-value indicates statistical significance.

caption: Table 3: The performance comparison with ID-based CF baselines. The improvement achieved by AlphaRec is significant (p-value << 0.05).
description: This table compares the performance of AlphaRec with various ID-based Collaborative Filtering (CF) methods across three datasets: Books, Movies & TV, and Video Games.  The metrics used are Recall@20, NDCG@20, and HR@20.  It highlights the significant improvement in performance that AlphaRec achieves compared to the baselines, emphasizing the statistical significance of these improvements.

caption: Table 3: The performance comparison with ID-based CF baselines. The improvement achieved by AlphaRec is significant (p-value << 0.05).
description: This table compares the performance of AlphaRec against several leading ID-based collaborative filtering (CF) methods across three Amazon datasets (Books, Movies & TV, and Video Games).  The metrics used are Recall@20, NDCG@20, and HR@20.  The table highlights AlphaRec's significant performance improvement over other methods, indicating its superior recommendation ability. The p-value << 0.05 indicates statistical significance of the improvements.

caption: Table 3: The performance comparison with ID-based CF baselines. The improvement achieved by AlphaRec is significant (p-value << 0.05).
description: This table compares the performance of AlphaRec against several state-of-the-art ID-based collaborative filtering methods across three datasets (Books, Movies & TV, Video Games).  The metrics used for comparison are Recall@20, NDCG@20, and HR@20.  The significant p-value indicates that AlphaRec's superior performance is statistically significant.
